questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with a right shift in Arneth count?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : C) Bone marrow suppression

Explanation: 

The presence of older neutrophils (N4 and N5) indicates suppression of bone marrow with a shift to the right in Arneth count.

The Arneth count is a method used to classify neutrophils as N1 to N5 based on the number of lobes in their nuclei.

 

Classification of Neutrophil
  • Class I: Myelocytes and neutrophils with indented or horseshoe-shaped nuclei. (5%)
  • Class II: Neutrophils with bilobed nuclei. (35%)
  • Class III: Neutrophils with tri-lobed nuclei. (41%)
  • Class IV: Neutrophils with four-lobed nuclei. (17%)
  • Class V: Neutrophils with five or more lobes in their nuclei. (2%)

Toxic Conditions
  • Fewer cells in Classes IV and V indicate a left-sided shift
  • Active tuberculosis often shows a left shift.      (Option A)
  • Other infections showing a left shift may have superimposed tuberculosis

Extrinsic Factors Influencing Arneth Count
  • Certain drugs, tissue extracts, and hormones.
  • Trauma , various forms of radiation.
  • Induction of anesthesia.

Infections and Arneth Count
  • Acute progressive infections: Notable left shift. (Option B)
  • As infection subsides: Less marked left shift, may shift to the right.
  • Chronic infections: Other features like lymphocytosis come into range.

Normal Neutrophil Distribution

N1 and N3 constitute most neutrophils in peripheral blood.

Bone Marrow Stimulation

Presence of younger neutrophils (N1 and N2) indicates stimulation of bone marrow (shift to the left).      (Option D)

Bone Marrow Suppression

Presence of older cells (N4 and N5) indicates suppression of bone marrow (shift to right) (Option C)

Hypersegmented Neutrophil

Seen in megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency (shift to right)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about platelets are true?

choices.text: Alpha granules contain clotting factors and platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)
Splenectomy causes a decrease in the platelet count
Interleukins IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, and IL-7 are involved in stimulating platelet production
Thrombopoietin is produced exclusively by megakaryocytes and regulates platelet production

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Alpha granules contain clotting factors and platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)

Explanation: Alpha granules are abundant in platelets, about 50-80 granules per platelet. They contain secreted proteins like clotting factors and platelet-derived growth factor(PDGF).

 

Platelets

General Description

Small, granulated, non-nucleated discs important for hemostasis

Size

1-4 µm in diameter

Concentration in Blood

150,000 - 450,000/µL

Half-life

~4 days

Origin

Formed from megakaryocytes in the bone marrow

Distribution

60-75% in circulation; the remainder mainly in the spleen

Splenectomy Effect

Causes an increase in platelet count (thrombocytosis) (Option B)

Thrombopoietin

Produced by liver and kidneys; regulates platelet production (Option D)

Membrane Receptors

For collagen, ADP, von Willebrand factor and fibrinogen

Cytoplasmic Components

Actin, myosin, glycogen, lysosomes and granules

Granules
  • Alpha granules: Soluble coagulation proteins (vWF, Factor V, II), adhesion molecule, growth factor (IGF, PDGF, TGF-β, platelet factor 4), Integrin, Cytokines (Option A)
  • Dense granules: ADP, ATP, Calcium, Serotonin

Response to Injury

Adhere to exposed collagen and von Willebrand factor; release granule contents upon activation

Deficiency Effect

Thrombocytopenic purpura (easy bruising, multiple subcutaneous hemorrhages)

Interleukins

IL-1, IL-3, IL-6, IL-11 stimulate platelet production (Option C)

Factors increasing platelet synthesis

Inflammation, thrombopoietin and IL-1, IL-3, IL-6, IL-11

questions.text: Which of the following coagulation factors is crucial for initiating the extrinsic pathway of blood coagulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Factor III

Explanation: Factor III, also known as Tissue thromboplastin, is responsible for the initiation of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.

Clotting Factors:

Clotting Factor

Synonyms

Function

Half life

I

Fibrinogen

Clot formation

3-5 days

II (Option A)

Prothrombin

  • Converts fibrinogen to fibrin
  • Activates platelets
  • Also has anti clotting activity
  • Has growth factor and cytokine like activities

60 hours

III (Option B)

Tissue thromboplastin
  • Initiator of extrinsic pathway of coagulation
  • Activates factor VII
  

-

IV

Calcium
  • Convert X to Xa
  • Convert prothrombin to thrombin

-

V (Option C)

Proaccelerin; labile factor; accelerator globulin (Ac-G)
  • Activate prothrombin to thrombin
  • Participates in activation of X

12 hours

VII (Option D)

Serum prothrombin conversion accelerator (SPCA); proconvertin; stable factor

Activates factor IX and X

3.5 hours

VIII

Antihemophilic factor(AHF); antihemophilic globulin(AHG); antihemophilic factor A

Activates factor X

8 - 12 hours

IX

Plasma thromboplastin component (PTC); antihemophilic factor B ; christmas factor

Activates factor X

18 - 24 hours

X

Stuart factor; Stuart-Prower factor

Conversion of prothrombin to thrombin

34 - 40 hours

XI

Plasma thromboplastin antecedent (PTA); antihemophilic factor C

Activates factor IX

45 hours

XII

Hageman factor; glass factor

Activates factor XI

-

XIII

Fibrin- stabilizing factor; Laki-Lorand factor

Crosslinks fibrin

10 days

Prekallikrein

Fletcher factor

Contact activation of blood coagulation

35 hours

High molecular weight kininogen (HMW-K)

Fitzgerald factor
  • Non enzymatic cofactor in contact activation
  • Act as thiol protease inhibitor

150 hours

Platelets phospholipid

PL
  • Temporary hemostasis
  • Synthesis factor V and XI

4 days

 

 

Deficiency of Factor

Clinical Syndrome

Cause

I

Afibrinogenemia

Depletion during pregnancy with premature separation of placenta; also congenital (rare)

II

Hypoprothrombinemia (hemorrhagic tendency in liver disease)

Decreased hepatic synthesis, often due to vitamin K deficiency

V

Parahemophilia

Congenital

VII

Congenital

(classic hemophilia)

Congenital defect in the gene on the X chromosome coding for factor VIII; inherited as a sex-linked characteristic.

IX

Hemophilia B
(Christmas disease)

Congenital

X

Stuart-Prower factor deficiency

Congenital

XI

Congenital

XII

Hageman trait

Congenital

choices.text: Platelet concentrates have a shelf life of up to 8 days at +22°C ± 2°C
Red cell concentrates stored with CPDA-1 have a shelf life of 35 days
Plasma stored at temperatures colder than –25°C has a shelf life of up to 3 years
Red cell concentrates stored with CPD have a shelf life of 28 days

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A)Platelet concentrates have a shelf life of up to 8 days at +22°C ± 2°C

Explanation: Platelets can be kept for as long as 8–13 days, but blood banks are only allowed to keep them for 5 days because of bacterial contamination.

Blood constituents

Preservative/

Shelf life

Uses

Temperature

Red cells

Citrate-citric acid- glucose (ACD) / 21 days

Blood transfusion

+4°C ± 2°C

Citrate phosphate dextrose (CPD) / 28 days (Option D)

CPDA-1(CPD with adenine) / 35 days (Option B)

CPD+ Additive solution / 42 days

Platelets

Plasma / 5-7 days
(5 days preferred due to bacterial risk) (Option A)

Platelet therapy

+22°C ± 2°C

Plasma

CPD,ACD, Buffered Citrate/ 3 years if frozen/ 3 months

Stable clotting factors (FII, FVII, FIX, FX, fibrinogen)

+4°C ± 2°C

Labile clotting factors (FV, FVIII)

3 years if colder than -25°C (Option C) / 3months if stored at -18°C to -25°C

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient needs an urgent blood transfusion. The image below shows the results of the patient’s blood group typing test. Based on the agglutination patterns observed, identify the patient's blood group?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  C) AB positive (AB+ve)

Explanation: In the above clinical scenario, the image shows agglutination with anti-A and anti-B and positive anti-D (Rh) sera, indicating the presence of A antigen, B antigen and positive Rh factor. Therefore, the blood group is AB positive (AB+ve).

A-B-O System:

Blood type

Antigens on RBC

Antibodies in Plasma

Genotypes

Frequency

O

-

Anti-A and Anti-B

OO

47%

A

A

Anti-B

OA or AA

41%

B

B

Anti-A

OB or BB

9%

AB

A and B

-

AB

3%

Landsteiner's Law states that if a particular agglutinogen is present on the red cell membrane of an individual, the corresponding agglutinin must be absent in his plasma and vice versa.

Agglutination test results:

H Antigen:

  • The H gene codes for fucose transferase, forming the H antigen, found in all blood types.
  • In addition, Type A adds N-acetylgalactosamine, Type B adds galactose, Type AB has both transferases, and Type O has neither, leaving the H antigen unchanged.
  • Blood group O with H antigen in plasma or saliva is called the OH group or Bombay (Oh : if H is not dominant).

Bombay Blood Group :

  • Phenotype: Oh, lacking the H gene and unable to form A or B antigens.
  • Identified as group O in routine tests, with serum containing anti-A, anti-B, and anti-H antibodies. Therefore transfusion can be done only with Bombay blood group.

Rh Factor :

Common Rh antigens

C, D, E, c, d and e

Detection

Only in red cells

D antigen

Most antigenic, defines Rh positive

No D antigen

Rh negative; Forms anti-D agglutinins upon exposure to Rh+ cells (Option B)

Prevalence

85% of whites Rh+ve ,15% Rh-ve

Over 99% of Asians Rh+ve

Anti-D antibody formation

Requires exposure (transfusion or feto-maternal blood transfer) to D-positive red cells

Transfusion reaction onset

Requires massive exposure to Rh antigen to produce enough agglutinins for significant transfusion reaction to develop

questions.text: A pediatrician is reviewing the development of hematopoiesis in a fetus at various stages of gestation. They are particularly interested in understanding the shifts in hematopoietic activity locations as the fetus develops. At which gestational age does the bone marrow become the primary site of hematopoiesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) At birth

Explanation:

At birth, hemopoiesis stops in liver and gets confined only to the bone marrow. Thus bone marrow becomes the primary site for hematopoiesis at birth . When hemopoiesis occurs in liver and spleen in postnatal life, is called extramedullary hemopoiesis .

Stage

Location

Key Points

Mesoblastic

Yolk sac, PSP, AGM
  • Yolk sac: Multilineage differentiating capabilities (starts functioning by the 2nd week of gestation).
  • Non-yolk sac regions: Para Aortic splanchnopleura (PSP) and aorta-gonad mesonephros (AGM) regions.
  • PSP: Gives rise to B-cell progenitors.
  • AGM: Contains pluripotent stem cells.

Hepatic

Liver, spleen
  • 2nd trimester of pregnancy.
  • Liver: Hematopoiesis starts at the 5th week, peaks at the 5th month, and ceases at birth.
  • Spleen: Hematopoiesis mainly in the 2nd trimester, less than liver.
  • Postnatal: Normally does not occur in liver and spleen unless demand is high (extramedullary hemopoiesis).

Medullary

Bone marrow (medullary hemopoiesis).
 
  • Marrow cavities appear by the 5th month (around 20 weeks) of fetal life, and become hemopoietic. (Option C)
  • Initial phase: Bone marrow exclusive for granulocytic and megakaryocytic proliferation.
  • Erythropoiesis starts in bone marrow towards the end of the 3rd trimester, and continues throughout life.
  • Postnatal: Hemopoiesis confined to bone marrow, extramedullary hemopoiesis abnormal.

 

Option A : At 3 to 6 weeks , hematopoiesis occur in yolk sac which starts functioning from 2 weeks of gestational age known as Mesoblastic stage.

 

Option B : At 6 to 8 weeks , hematopoiesis occur in liver which starts functioning from 5 weeks of gestational age, peaks at 5th month and ceases at birth , known as Hepatic stage.

Option C : Around 20 weeks : Hematopoiesis  starts to occur in the bone marrow around 20 weeks but liver becomes the major site of hematopoiesis.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the behavior of hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) and wants to understand the mechanisms that regulate their self-renewal during tissue repair. Which type of stem cell division increases the stem cell pool during tissue repair?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Symmetric division

 

Explanation:

Symmetric division results in both daughter cells retaining stem cell properties, thereby increasing the stem cell pool, which is crucial during tissue repair.
 

Pathway

Definition

Mechanisms / Factors

Signaling Pathways

Self-Renewal

Produces at least one daughter cell with stem cell properties

Symmetric and Asymmetric Division

Wnt, Notch, TGF-β

Differentiation

Produces specialized cell types

Transcription Factors, Microenvironmental Signals

Wnt, Notch, TGF-β

Both Pathways

Balance between self-renewal and differentiation to maintain stem cell pool and tissue function

Interplay of intrinsic and extrinsic factors

  

Stem cell types and their properties:

Stem Cell Type

Description

Example

Totipotent Stem Cells

Can generate the entire organism, including the placenta.

Single cell from the 8-cell embryo stage.

Pluripotent Stem Cells

Can generate the entire organism except the placenta.

Cells from the inner cell mass of the blastocyst.

Multipotent Stem Cells

Can form only one lineage of cells.

Hematopoietic stem cells that give rise to various blood cell types.

Steps in hematopoiesis:

Multipotent Stem Cell ➜ Progenitor Cell ➜ Precursor Cell ➜ Mature Cell
Mature Cell: Differentiated cell with decreased self-renewal and proliferation properties.

  • Hematopoietic Stem Cells: Convert to multipotent stem cells, giving rise to two progenitor types.
  • Memory B and T Cells are mature cells but have the ability to self-renew and proliferate.

 

 

Asymmetric division (Option A) – Maintains homeostasis by generating one stem cell and one differentiated cell, rather than expanding the pool.

Terminal differentiation (Option C) – Leads to fully specialized cells with no further division

Lateral inhibition (Option D) – A process in which a cell inhibits its neighboring cells from adopting the same fate, playing a role in cell differentiation rather than expanding the stem cell pool.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the Burst Forming Unit-Erythroid (BFU-E) in the process of erythropoiesis?

choices.text: It is a mature red blood cell that participates in oxygen transport
It is a type of stem cell that can differentiate into any blood cell type
It is an early progenitor cell in erythropoiesis that gives rise to CFU-E
It is a precursor cell in erythropoiesis that directly produces reticulocytes

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It is an early progenitor cell in erythropoiesis that gives rise to CFU-E

Explanation:

Erythropoiesis:

 

Since hemoglobin is not present in BFU-E, it can not transport oxygen. (Option A)

Multipotent hematopoietic stem cell gives rise to all the cells circulating in blood. (Option B)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding erythropoietin is not true?

choices.text: It is majorly produced by the liver
Major stimulus for its production is hypoxia
The maximum erythropoietin receptor density is seen on CFU-E

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) It is majorly produced by the liver

 

Explanation:

 

Erythropoietin:

  • It is the major regulator of erythropoiesis, which increases the number of RBCs in blood by acting on the JAK STAT pathway (Option C).
  • Erythropoietin is synthesized from:
    • Kidney (around 90%) (Option A)
    • Liver
    • Brain
  • The major stimulus for erythropoietin production is Low oxygen levels or tissue hypoxia (Option B).
  • When there is tissue hypoxia, erythropoietin acts on Burst forming unit-Erythroid (BFU-E), converting them into colony forming unit-Erythroid (CFU-E), which has the maximum erythropoietin receptor density (Option D).
  • CFU-E on the continued action of erythropoietin converts into proerythrocytes and following.

questions.text: How many oxygen atoms can one molecule of hemoglobin bind?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 8

 

Explanation:

 

Hemoglobin:

  • Hb synthesis begins in the polychromatophil erythroblasts.
  • The most common form of hemoglobin found in adults is HbA, which is a combination of 2 alpha chains and 2 beta chains.
  • The heme group in one Hb molecule has 4 atoms of iron, which binds to 4 molecules of oxygen or 8 atoms of oxygen (option D)
  • Therefore, each Hb molecule carries 4 oxygen molecules to the tissues.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary protein responsible for binding and transporting free heme in the bloodstream?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hemopexin

 

Explanation:

 

  • Hemopexin is a primary protein that is responsible for binding and transporting free heme in the bloodstream.
  • When RBC undergoes hemolysis, heme is released into the blood.
  • Free heme is potentially toxic due to its ability to generate reactive oxygen species and cause oxidative damage.
  • Hemopexin binds to free heme with high affinity, facilitating safe transport of the liver for degradation and prevention of toxicity (option D).

 

Haptoglobin binds free hemoglobin, but not free heme (Option A)

 

Albumin maintains osmotic pressure and serves as a carrier protein for various substances, including hormones, fatty acids, and drugs, but is not a carrier of heme (Option B)

 

Transferrin is responsible for transfer of iron in the bloodstream. (Option C)

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with asthma presents with persistent coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath. Which interleukin is most directly involved in the activation of eosinophils in this condition?
questions.solution:
In an allergic reaction, the leukocytes most involved are eosinophils. The interleukin involved in eosinophilia is IL-5.

Leukopoiesis:

 

Factors involved in leukopoiesis:

  • Colony-stimulating factors such as G-CSF and GM-CSF
  • IL-5 is required for differentiation of leukocytes into eosinophils (Option C)
  • IL-3 & 4 are required for the development of basophils (Option B ruled out)

 

IL-1 is responsible for the activation of T cells and macrophages and the promotion of inflammation (Option A ruled out)

IL-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that regulates immune reactions. (Option D ruled out)
